repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This mostly means replacing `nvim_buf_call` and `nvim_win_call` with
`vim._with`.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -367,26 +367,26 @@ describe('autocmd', function()
     -- This used to crash after making aucmd_win a normal window via the above.
     exec_lua [[
       vim.cmd "tabnew | tabclose # | wincmd s | wincmd _"
-      vim.api.nvim_buf_call(_G.buf, function() vim.cmd "wincmd K" end)
+      vim._with({buf = _G.buf}, function() vim.cmd "wincmd K" end)
     ]]
     assert_alive()
     screen:expect_unchanged()
 
     -- Also check with win_splitmove().
     exec_lua [[
-      vim.api.nvim_buf_call(_G.buf, function()
+      vim._with({buf = _G.buf}, function()
         vim.fn.win_splitmove(vim.fn.winnr(), vim.fn.win_getid(1))
       end)
     ]]
     screen:expect_unchanged()
 
     -- Also check with nvim_win_set_config().
     matches(
-      ': Failed to move window %d+ into split$',
+      'Failed to move window %d+ into split$',

comment_data.body:
I'd recommend using more targeted scopes for options. As `isfname` is global option, I'd use `go` instead of `o`.
It seems to make code more explicit while avoiding [extra step in implementation](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/fc9b70826ec88ca2e6c0624c522b872e87aa7ac1/runtime/lua/vim/shared.lua#L1183) that decided which scope should be used.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,10 +180,9 @@ function M._get_url()
     end
   end
 
-  local old_isfname = vim.o.isfname
-  vim.cmd [[set isfname+=@-@]]
-  local url = vim.fn.expand('<cfile>')
-  vim.o.isfname = old_isfname
+  local url = vim._with({ o = { isfname = vim.o.isfname .. ',@-@' } }, function()

comment_data.body: Hmm... I wonder why this test changes was necessary? On paper `vim._with({ buf = buf }, f)` seems to work exactly as `vim.api.nvim_buf_call(buf, f)`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -367,26 +367,26 @@ describe('autocmd', function()
     -- This used to crash after making aucmd_win a normal window via the above.
     exec_lua [[

       end)

     -- Also check with nvim_win_set_config().
     matches(
-      ': Failed to move window %d+ into split$',
+      '^Failed to move window %d+ into split$',

comment_data.body: Just using different error functions I think. `vim._with` uses `nlua_push_errstr` while `nvim_buf_call` uses `api_set_error`. I don't think it makes a real difference which you use.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -367,26 +367,26 @@ describe('autocmd', function()
     -- This used to crash after making aucmd_win a normal window via the above.
     exec_lua [[
       vim.cmd "tabnew | tabclose # | wincmd s | wincmd _"
-      vim.api.nvim_buf_call(_G.buf, function() vim.cmd "wincmd K" end)
+      vim._with({buf = _G.buf}, function() vim.cmd "wincmd K" end)
     ]]

+      '^Failed to move window %d+ into split$',

comment_data.body: I don't think that's more correct. If `isfname` becomes global-local in the future, won't `vim.go` be incorrect (since we're changing the default/global value rather than the value of the buffer)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,10 +180,9 @@ function M._get_url()
     end
   end
 
-  local old_isfname = vim.o.isfname
-  vim.cmd [[set isfname+=@-@]]
-  local url = vim.fn.expand('<cfile>')
-  vim.o.isfname = old_isfname
+  local url = vim._with({ o = { isfname = vim.o.isfname .. ',@-@' } }, function()

comment_data.body:
*If* 'isfname' scopes are changed, *then* using `bo` or `wo` here will be better. Right now this option is sensible to be used with `go`, as its scope is global. Using `o` as scope here will only lead to more work done during this function execution with the same result as `go`.

That said, It is not particularly strong opinion per se.

comment_regular_data.body:
> Do we have (explicit) tests that verify that options/etc are restored even when `f()` throws an error?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29280

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor: use `vim._with` where possible
